Nice pic! Looks like he's shaving a piece of aluminum down because of how much material and how deep the tool is. I see he is not wearing OSHA approved safety glasses, no side shield. Also wearing a long sleeve shirt is usually not a good idea when working around rotating machinery but I'm willing to bet he's been doing this for a while. It would be cool to maybe have some of the machinists tools layed out on a workbench for a little foreground interest.
I'm all for eliminating drug use, now we need to ship him some ammo!

Nice sunset colors! I like the old barn but the part of the house on the left is distracting and not adding anything to the pic. The foreground has nothing of interest and is under exposed and that will will always happen with such a high contrast scene unless you either use a graduated filter on the bright part of the scene or use HDR.
I definately like the first pic better, the bush on the left is too much. Have fun with your new lens!

Man I would love to be there! The lake is perfectly smooth and the mountain top has some snow. The low cloud is cool, you can see the rocks under water and the reflection of the mountain is just right. I honestly don't know how I would be able to make this shot "better". Awesome job!

I've been getting back into film photography and have visited my local labs that still develop film here in Fort Worth. At first I googled 1 hour photo places...needless to say I didn't find any, it's been a long time. Anyway, after visiting these places and seeing what they have to offer I have been going through my old slides and negatives to see if any are worth being scanned and adjusted in Photoshop. I have found several where the exposure wasn't just right or the color balance was weird and I might be able turn them into something worth printing!
You should check out r/photocritique! You can post single pics and ask for advise.

I used to live in Fairbanks Alaska and the light there was awesome. I was only able to get a few good shots of the way the light looked during the 4 years I was there, it is very hard to get it right. I like your shot of the guy training for cross country skiing! You can tell he is going all out because of the steam coming off from him, it's great!
Thank you for the tips!
Thank you for thinking about my photo! If it helps this is a ring gear from a locomotive axle. Do you think it would be better for me to explain the pic when posting?

I was experimenting with composition and isolating an industrial type of subject to make an interesting photo. I was actually bored at work last night and thought it might look cool. I have no plans to print it, although it might look good in someone's mancave.

Yea that's a hard scene to capture because of the high contrast between the sky with the mist and the relatively dark foreground with the hill and tree detail. Unless you do an HDR shot or if using film some Kodak Ektar 100 might get good results. Also next time maybe try to get more of the sky in the shot and less of the foreground, that will help emphasize the sunrise. I really like the pine trees on the left, maybe try getting more of them. Good luck and thanks for posting!
Perhaps you should have exposed for the trees and bushes, I bet there was some nice foreground interest in the bottom half of the image but I can't tell because it's all black.
An awesome sunset would be sweet. Or maybe a bad looking storm with a lightning bolt. You could use a flash to light the house so it's not blacked out by the background.

That's true, there are a lot of people who have been doing this a lot longer than myself. Also there are some pros that get paid to go around and get awesome shots. Like this guy: http://www.marcadamus.com I want his job!
For me it's a little disheartening to look at all of those awesome landscape photos because none of mine come close.
You will find what you are looking for at www.photo.net

I don't know of any one stop source of info for what you are looking for. The period you are talking about is the point in history where warfare changed from guys marching around in actual formations and each side standing in a field firing at each other with muskets all the way to the first nuclear bomb being dropped. There is a lot going on in that time frame with evolving technology, such as the invention of the machine gun, which forced a change in tactics. It may be easier to concentrate on separate wars and the tactics used and what weapons were in use during those wars. Wikipedia has a bunch of info to get you started. Look at "infantry tactics", looks like it starts at the beginning. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_strategy
I like to bomb the downhill sections and I always stay clipped in. The only time I unclip is usually going slow around a sharp corner...I don't like bashing my knees into rocks if I fall over.
I thought it was a woman in the shot.
The only thing I can think of to make this scene better would be either rain or snow just to emphasize how much these guys are out there getting stuff done. I like it!
I use time z pedals...its a clip in pedal with a platform for when things get sketchy and I might have to bail which isn't very often. So I say both.

I'm going back to film vs blowing a ton of money on a new DSLR. Just got a Minolta SRT 101 from ebay a couple weeks ago, it was made in the 60's and still works. I did have a Canon G11 until it broke, maybe lasted 3 or 4 years. For now I'm done with fragile plastic cameras.
Nice fall colors! Not sure what he is taking a pic of though with that long lens? Is there one without the guy in it?

If you go through Glacier NP you can also hit up Banff NP in Canada and check out the West Edmonton Mall if you're into that kind of stuff. If you plan on camping in the Youkon don't forget they have bears there so bring bear mace and practice food safety.
Get a book called the milepost, it details every store and gas station along the way along with operating hours. Also don't rely on your cellphone map, or the ability to make phone calls.
Definately Glacier

I try to ask myself what if I were there taking the pic and how could I make it "better". After all this is personal opinion. So to me this kind of shot needs the right light and this isn't it. I would have either gotten up early or stayed later to get the sunrise/sunset. Looks like you were facing the sun on this shot which makes for too much contrast between the sky and the ground and you have to choose which one you want to expose for or use a graduated filter on the sky to even out the contrast between the two. My 2 cents.

My opinion is it changes with your age or responsibility level. If your a kid and don't have much to actually worry about then you can lay around and watch YouTube videos all day and you should be fine. Kids used to lay around and watch TV all day and for the most part they are fine. As an adult you will need to support yourself somehow. After you get that part done then back to the Internet if that's what you like to do with your spare time. It's a free country after all so do what you want.

You almost perfectly nailed the thirds composition "rule". So it looks like you used some kind of graduated filter to make the top half of the sky artificially dark and a polarizer to make the clouds look like they do. That or it's HDR. Other than the background the colors look washed out...seems like the ocean should be more blue and the foreground should be brighter since it is sunny out.

Maybe next time get everyone in the shade because the direct sunlight on some but not others throws off the exposure. Also try using the biggest aperture opening (smallest number) so the background is more out of focus while keeping the people in the front in focus. Also it looks there is a random tree island floating in the pool, try not including that next time.
At first when I opened the pic I thought it was an advertisement for 500px! I agree, great composition but the light is flat. Hopefully you can go back and get more!
Maybe try getting closer to the rock, like 20 feet away and don't get the sign in the shot but keep the upper color in the trees in it.
The ass in the background is distracting. Maybe used a little higher shutter speed to keep her hand from blurring. Exposure is good!

To me it looks like the main subject, the building, is under exposed. If you relied on your cameras meter settings the (relatively) bright lights tricked it into underexposing everything else. If your camera has exposure compensation you can adjust for this. Nice composition though!
Looks like you got the exposure right! The black background is solid and not washed out looking so that is a plus.

Nice car! The weeds in the foreground are a little distracting. The building in the background looks interesting, maybe include more of that. Also do you use a polarizer? If not it would help get rid of the glare on the car.
You just described one of the fight scenes on the movie Hero.

We didn't have electricity from the grid until I was 5. My dad had rigged up an old engine and an army surplus generator which he used to charge car batteries inside our trailer. Once they were charged he would hook them up to an inverter to run the TV and lights. We had one of those old little black and white tv's and when the batteries would start going dead the picture would get smaller and smaller until it went out which meant it was time for bed.
Looks like you found yourself a nice keen kutter ax! I'd like to have that one hanging on my wall next to my double bit ax and hatchet. They all have good handles too, good finds!
